card.title: Chess Log Tournament
card.content: Automates tournament management: result entry, Swiss-system pairings and live standings.

card.title: SoftDesk API
card.content: RESTful API for project tracking, secured by a permission system.

content.01: This RESTful API lets users create and manage projects. Coordinate work with contributors through tickets and comments, and keep everyone organized with clearly defined roles.
content.07: database. It features JWT authentication, fine-tuned permissions, and filters on every list endpoint to quickly find the wanted resource.

content.01: This was my first full API project: relational modeling, nested serializers, and HATEOAS-style routes using drf-nested-routers. I implemented JWT authentication plus a custom permission scheme to isolate and secure each project.
content.02: Tooling side: I produced a comprehensive Postman collection and added dynamic filters.

card.title: Epic Events CRM
card.content: Customer Relationship Management, centralizing and unifying collaborator data across departments that previously relied on isolated Excel sheets.

content.01: Epic Events CRM is a CLI-based CRM designed to consolidate client and collaborator data. It provides a structured database for managing and processing client's events.
content.02: The project was deliberately over-engineered to test the feasibility of applying Domain-Driven Design principles, the Repository pattern, and the Unit of Work pattern within a Python CLI context.
content.03: It uses <bold>SQLAlchemy</bold> (Imperative ORM) with <bold>PostgreSQL</bold> as the database backend, wrapped in a layered architecture to ensure clear separation of concerns.
content.04: Permissions are enforced through RCAB and ACAB to allow fine-grained access, while Sentry provides error monitoring.

content.01: This project taught me how to implement DDD-inspired architecture in Python. Encapsulation of operations and abstract interfaces with Repositories and Unit of Works, designing entities and services to maintain a layered codebase.
content.02: On the dev tool side, I built tests with Pytest and managed packaging and dependencies with uv.
content.03: My key takeaway from this project: patterns bring structure, but they also introduced significant code complexity. If over-engineering was intentional here, I shall restrain from implementing design pattern without a clear goal in mind in the future.
